msIdentifier.repository: Gonville and Caius College, Lower Library
msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 105/57

summary.seg: This composite manuscript consists of two 14th-century volumes of medical works. The presence of two lists of the contents of both volumes (pp. [ii] recto (bound upside-down) and 3 (lower margin)) written by the hand of physician Roger Marchall Rogerus Marshall (c. 1417-1477) (fl. 1436-1477), shows that the two portions were bound together by this time.

The parchment flyleaves at the beginning have been taken from two other manuscripts. The first comes from a 15th-century English account book. The next two comprise a bifolium, including an empty leaf to which the aforementioned table of contents was added, and the opening of a 14th-century copy of De miseria condicionis humanae by Cardinal Lotario dei Segni, later Pope Innocent III.

As described by Linda Voigts, the present manuscript is one of eighteen (possibly nineteen) manuscripts at Gonville and Caius College that may be linked to Marchall, and which were probably donated by him to Gonville Hall (as Gonville and Caius then was); King's College and Peterhouse, where the study of medicine was also supported, received gifts of books from him too.

Thirteen manuscripts owned or used by Marchall (and another with possible Marchall connections) have been digitised, catalogued and conserved as part of the Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries project:
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 59/153 (Voigts 1995, no. 2)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 98/50 (Voigts 1995, no. 4)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 105/57 (Voigts 1995, no. 5)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 159/209 (Voigts 1995, no. 9)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 178/211 (Voigts 1995, no. 10)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 181/214 (Voigts 1995, no. 11)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 345/620 (Voigts 1995, no. 12)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 373/593 (Voigts 1995, no. 13)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 379/599 (Voigts 1995, no. 14)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 401/623 (Voigts 1995, no. 16)
Cambridge, Peterhouse, MS 95 (Voigts 1995, no. 24)
Cambridge, Peterhouse, MS 222 (Voigts 1995, no. 28)
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.8.31 (Voigts 1995, no. 29)
Cambridge, University Library, MS Add. 9213 (possible Marchall connections) (Voigts 1995, no. 48)

Dr Clarck Drieshen
Project Cataloguer
Cambridge University Library

References: See L. Voigts, 'A doctor and his books: the manuscripts of Roger Marchall (d. 1477)', in R. Beadle and A. J. Piper (eds.), New science out of old books: studies in manuscripts and early printed books in honour of A.I. Doyle (Aldershot, 1995) pp. 249-314

supportDesc.support: This manuscript comprises two volumes of parchment leaves that have been joined together.

foliation.note: Pagination numbering in brown ink (1-301) in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos only.

signatures.p: Quire numbering in purple crayon in the lower right-hand corner of the recto side of the first leaf of each quire, written by a 20th-century hand.

note.p: A parchment pastedown on the inside of the upper cover with a 17th-century title inscription.

A table of contents (bound upside down) for both parts of the manuscript on p. [ii] recto entitled: 'Contenta in hoc volumine sunt ista', written in the second or third quarter of the 15th-century by Roger Marchall (fl. 1436-1477), doctor of medicine.
A second table of contents for both parts of the manuscript added by Roger Marchall in the lower margin of p. 3.

provenance.p: Roger Marchall (fl. 1436-1477), doctor of medicine Marchall, Roger, fl. 1436-1477: his name 'R. Marchall' inscribed on pp. [ii] recto and 2. See L. Voigts, 'A doctor and his books: the manuscripts of Roger Marchall (d. 1477)', in R. Beadle and A. J. Piper (eds.), New science out of old books: studies in manuscripts and early printed books in honour of A.I. Doyle (Aldershot, 1995) pp. 249-314 (p. 270 and plates 43(a), 43(b), and 48(b).

history.acquisition: Probably donated by Roger Marchall Marchall, Roger, fl. 1436-1477 to Gonville and Caius College with other manuscripts, but certainly in the college's library by the year 1600, when it was recorded as no. 132 (p. 2)in the Ecloga Oxonio-Cantabrigiensis by Thomas James (1600). Also no. 971 (f. inside of the front cover) in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697). The College's printed armorial bookplate with handwritten classmark numbers '57' and '105' feature on a paper pastedown on the inside of the front cover; and its number '105' handwritten on a paper pastedown on f. [i] recto.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry partly draws on M. R. James, A descriptive catalogue of the manuscripts in the library of Gonville and Caius College, vol. 1 (Cambridge, 1908), pp. 105-106.

availability.p: Visitors to Gonville and Caius College who wish to consult Lower Library material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Gonville and Caius College: Library Information.

monogr.title: Glossulae quatuor magistrorum super Chirurgiam Rogerii et Rolandi: nunc primum ad fidem codicis Mazarinei edidit
The Cyrurgia magna of Brunus Longoburgensis: A Critical Edition

imprint.publisher: Unpublished doctoral dissertation, University of Oxford

analytic.title: A doctor and his books: the manuscripts of Roger Marchall (d. 1477)

monogr.title: New science out of old books: studies in manuscripts and early printed books in honour of A.I. Doyle
Manuscripts in the Library of Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 105/57, f. [i]

msItem.title: Account book
msItem.incipit: [i] recto Et de domino nostro Rege etcaetera
msItem.note: [i] verso was probably a pastedown on the inside of a previous cover; the text on this page is badly damaged and only contains fragments of sentences where the glue has not been torn or scraped off.
A few names are legible, including: 'quondam domini de Scroop' (p. [i] recto) and 'ffrancisco venelly' (p. [i] verso).

supportDesc.condition: The text on f. [i] recto has been partially smudged while the text on p. [i] verso has been badly damaged with glue.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only. 28 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Written in a cursive script with both Anglicana and Secretary features.

decoNote.p: Loops in brown ink on the ascenders of letters.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 105/57, f. [ii], pp. 1-2

msItem.title: Pangram
msItem.incipit: [ii] recto Equore cum gelido Zephirus fert
msItem.note: Full transcription of the pangram which is missing the words 'exennia kymbus'
Added to the page in a 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Medical note
msItem.incipit: [ii] verso Practica ignota de omnibus morbus medendis
msItem.note: Added to the page in a 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: De miseria condicionis humanae
msItem.author: Lotario dei Conti di Segni [later Pope Innnocent III]
msItem.rubric: 1 De contemptu mundi: Innocencius papa tercius
msItem.incipit: 1 Domino patri karissimo Petro dei gracia portuensi Episcopo Lotarius indignus diaconus cardinalis gloriam in presenti et gloriam in futuro
msItem.explicit: 2 An illud forsan respondebit quod adam ipse fuit formatus

supportDesc.condition: Previously folded along the upper and outer margins.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, line ruling only. Single columns. 31 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Written by a single hand from the the 14th century in Northern Gothica Textualis Formata.

decoNote.p: Five-line puzzle initial in blue and red with red penwork decoration inside the letter, featuring floral motifs and a hybrid figure (? dragon), and a partial (one-sided) border in blue and red ink.
Three large (2-3 lines) initials alternating between blue and red with penwork decoration inside the letters in, respectively, red and purple.
A one-line capital in blue opening the rubricated title on p. 1.
One-line capitals highlighted in red ink.

A bearded human head in red ink drawn attached to the ascender of the rubricated initial 'I' on the upper line of p. 1, and a head with headdress in blue ink drawn attached to and below the initial 'N' on the last line of p. 2.
Headers rubricated in red ink.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 105/57, ff. 2-249

msContents.textLang: Latin texts with additions in Middle English and Middle French

msItem.title: Chirurgia, with the additions of Roland of Parma
msItem.author: Roger Frugardi
msItem.rubric: 3 Incipit cyrurgia rogeri cum addicionibus Rolandi parmensis
msItem.explicit: 74 Roget ergo creatorem nostrum uestra benignitas ut omnium mihi ueniam dignetur concedere peccatorum
msItem.finalRubric: 74 Explicit expliceat ludere scriptor eat. finito libro reddatur cena magistro amen

msItem.title: Glosses on Roland's reworking of Roger Frugardi's Chirurgia
msItem.author: The Four Masters (medical glossators)
msItem.incipit: 75 Sicut dicit constuntinus [sic: constantinus] humores temperamentum exeuntes faciunt causam morbi
msItem.explicit: 162 Omnis superfluitas cibi et potus eis interdicatur Comedat bis in die quoniam comedere semel nocet eit sicut dicit auicenna. Explicit
msItem.note: Glossulae quatuor magistrorryn super chirurgiam Rogerii et Rolandi.

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.note: Recipe for the stomach, added in the late 14th-century.

msItem.title: Chirurgia maior [Chirurgia magna]
msItem.author: Bruno da Longoburgo
msItem.explicit: 249 Inter tum eius dentes aliquod locetur ne cum motus in uoluntarius superuenerit dencium constrictione lingua ledatur et custodiatur ne frigus eum capiat et accidant sibi peiora prioribus

msItem.title: Prologue to the Chirurgia maior [Chirurgia magna]
msItem.author: Bruno da Longoburgo
msItem.incipit: 249 Anno ab incarnatione domini .M.o cc.o lii.o mense Jannuari inditione in ciuitate padue in loco sancti pauli
msItem.explicit: 249 deus omnipotens tibi graciam suam inspiret te que ad cognitionem me melioris perducat amen

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: A recipe for an ointment for sores, and an instruction for extracting worms from a man's body, added in the late 14th-century.

p.secFol: 5De polipo et de signis curabilis polipi

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in brown ink on last versos of Quires 1-6

supportDesc.condition: There is hole in p. 50 with sewing holes around it. Stains on pp. 118-119.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and line ruling. Single columns. 40 lines to page, written below top line.

handNote.p: pp. 3-162 have been copied in Textualis Libraria.
pp. 163-249 have been copied in in Southern Semitextualis Libraria.
The Middle French and Middle English recipes on pp. 75 and 250 have been added by two late 14th-century hands writing in Anglicana.

decoNote.p: Large puzzle initials in blue and red with penwork decoration inside the letter and pen-flourishing extending into the margins on; pp. 3, 5, 36, 51, 69, 116, 136, 154, 163, 214; usually five to six lines, but a seven-line initial on p. 3 and a ten-line initial on p. 75.
Two-line initials alternatively in blue and red with minor forms of penwork decoration and pen-flourishing in the opposite colour throughout.
One-line initials alternating between blue and red in lists of chapters on pp. 4-5, 35-36, 50-51, 164-165, 214.
One-line capitals in brown ink, some featuring minor forms of decoration including human faces, highlighted in light brown ink on pp. 3-13 and occasionally in red ink after that.

Line-fillers with floral motifs and zoomorphic figures in brown and red ink on pp. 4-5, and with plain motifs in red ink after that, but one with knotwork motifs (p. 27) and another with floral motifs (p. 74).
Human heads in brown ink attached to initials on pp. 6, 23, 44 [with a hunting horn]. Floral motifs attached to initials on pp. 3, 6, 7, 15, 19, 20, , 39.
Headings rubricated in red ink throughout.
Paraphs alternating between blue and red throughout; red paraphs occasionally with pen-flourishing.
Run-over symbols decorated with floral motifs in brown and red ink on pp. 4, 57, 70, 85.
Marginal drawings in brown and red ink, including a hunting horn (p. 12), a floral motif (p. 16), a human head (pp. 17 and 110), a dog and hare (p. 123).
Manicules in the margins of pp. 4, 6 [2x], 11, 15.
An drawing of a human head added to 14 lines of text on p. 85.

additions.p: Medical recipes added in margins by a 14th-century hand on pp. 13, 90-91, including a list of the sun's location in the astrological signs of the Zodiac for each month of the year.
The table of contents in the lower margin of p. 3 added by Roger Marchall (c. 1417-1477) Rogerus Marshall (c. 1417-1477) , who also added titles at the beginning of works on pp. 75, 163, 178.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 105/57, pp. 251-302

msItem.title: Treatise with medical cures
msItem.incipit: 251 De allopicia: contra allopiciam et causm capillorum
msItem.explicit: 302 auri et argenti an[...] .3.s. conficiantur cum zucaro
msItem.note: The rubric has been partly effaced and the work has not been identified. However, its structure closely matches with the Practica of William of Brescia [Guglielmo Corvi], as printed in Excellentissimi medici Guilielmi Brixiensis aggregatoris dictorum illustrium medicorum ad unamquamque egritudinem a capite ad pedes practica, nunc primum ad communem usum edita et impressa. Ejusdem de febribus tractatus optimus, de peste, de consilio observando tempore pestilentiali, ac etiam de cura pestis tractatus perspicuus ejusdem (Venice: Scottus, 1508), although the manuscript omits its discussions of the symptoms and causes of ailments, and presents cures only.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords written in brown ink in the lower rigth-hand corners of final versos.

supportDesc.condition: There are holes in the leaves that cover pp. 287-288 and pp. 291-292, but without loss of text.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and line ruling. Double columns. 40 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Written by a singe scribe in a Textualis Currens.

decoNote.p: Two-line initials alternatively in red and blue with penwork decoration inside the letter in the opposite colour occur throughout.
Headers rubricated in red ink throughout.
Paraphs in red throughout.

note.p: Added Latin recipes in different 14th-century 15th-century hands in the margins of pp. 280, 286, and 299.
A drawing of a human head in brown ink with the text 'Raw and sedgh' in a 15th-century script in the lower margin of p. 287.
